I would like to turn to the first point that the minister cites as achieving something that they are committed to, and that is the question of savings. Since this program was first identified by the government, the rhetoric attached to it was that savings were the primary objective. Yet consistently we have seen the government fluctuate on the level of savings they hope to achieve. Indeed, the minister's most recent contribution on this issue no longer talks about $1 billion worth of savings over seven years but a mere $270 million over five years. Why is this the case?

Let us have a look at a retrospective analysis. The government have not been able to deliver on the program that they outlined initially for a number of reasons. First and foremost, it is structurally flawed. Out of three tenders that have been let specifically under this program, there has been a trail of mismanagement that involves one tender not even attracting a competitor beyond a significant player in IBM GSA. I am referring to the DETYA tender which, despite being set up supposedly as a flagship of the IT outsourcing program, managed to attract no more than one tender bid in that process. That was subsequently cancelled.

Another example is the original contract that was let by the Department of Finance and Administration. After announcing the IT outsourcing program, they decided to flout the whole principle of what they had espoused about using competitive practice to achieve cost savings and awarded the department of finance's IT outsourcing contract directly to a company by the name of IBM GSA, without having embarked upon a competitive process for that tender. For those who have been following this debate, that was the notorious piggyback tender, where the provisions of an IT contract with the Department of Veterans' Affairs were extended across another department, that of Finance.

So you can see with just those two examples that the government has tripped its way through what is a structurally flawed process to the point where Minister Fahey has no choice but to continue to espouse empty rhetoric about the virtues of this program. As I said, it is certainly not delivering on the cost savings. Indeed, it will be interesting to see how they expect to justify, in the broader sense, the cost savings.

I would now like to refer to a recent publication entitled `Information technology outsourcing—practices, lessons and prospects' by Professors Leslie Willcocks and Mary C. Lacity. This particular report identifies a range of issues that are absolutely pertinent to IT outsourcing and its place in Australian Commonwealth procurement and the development of our IT industry sector. Willcocks and Lacity cite in their studies a particular element of their research. I would like to quote from this particular article, which states:

The second source of evidence is provided by our forthcoming book Global Information Technology Outsourcing: Search For Business Advantage . Here we establish the outcomes from 116 IT sourcing case histories in the 1990-98 period. The metrics used were: organisational objectives against results; cost reductions achieved against anticipated; and satisfaction levels established by the organisation by, for example, user satisfaction questionnaires, level of disputes, invoking of penalty clauses.

This study has been carried out by Willcocks and Lacity with the view to assessing the relative merits of IT outsourcing as a practice per se and its ability to deliver on the proposed outcomes, which as we have heard relate specifically, as far as this government is concerned, to cost savings.

The figure that that paragraph I just quoted refers to shows that, in terms of total outsourcing, 38 per cent rate it as a success, 35 per cent rate it as a failure and 27 per cent identify a mixed response. In terms of selective outsourcing, which is a different approach, a far higher success rate is cited of 77 per cent, with a failure rate of 20 per cent and a mixed response of three per cent.

It is worth while extrapolating on this because selective IT outsourcing emerges as a differing model. It is certainly one that I have identified in the progress of this debate as being a far more worthy model for the government to consider, if they are indeed serious about not only the success of applying an outsourcing model but also acting in the interests of Australia's economy and the critical emerging sector of information technology and our innovation in this country. Again I quote from Willcocks and Lacity:

Selective IT outsourcing emerges as the most effective practice, closely followed by the in-house route. Underlining the survey results above, we found successful selective outsourcers embracing several distinctive practices. They had more limited and realistic expectations, signed short (two- to four-year) contracts for which the business and technical requirements remained relatively stable, kept in-house resource and knowledge to fall back on (resulting in less power asymmetry developing in favour of the vendor and lower potential switching costs), often leveraged competition through using multiple suppliers, and found ways in the contract to provide incentives for the supplier and build in flexibility.

That paragraph really sits in complete opposition to what the current experience is under the government's IT outsourcing program. In their clustered, vertically integrated, laterally grouped or clustered contracts that exist under the IT outsourcing program, they actually define a situation where not only do small Australian IT companies not have the opportunity to participate directly in these contracts but indeed they ensure that only the very large multinational companies have the opportunity to do so.

Whereas the selective sourcing model identifies an opportunity for adaption to the rapid technological change that is taking place, it also empowers the client—the person purchasing the services from the IT vendors—to have a degree of flexibility and strategic control over the management of information technology in that particular workplace. In this case what we are seeing is the government following the opposite path to what is espoused within that selective sourcing model, to the detriment of Australian industry and certainly to the detriment of the Commonwealth agencies and departments who are seeking to utilise IT outsourcing as a means of improving services to the citizens of Australia through their department's or agency's goals and indeed serving the political purpose of delivering some cost savings, which I have already addressed and provided some comment on. So I think that clearly, through these studies, the actual justification or the comments that I originally referred to from the minister with respect to savings and improving the quality of service delivery from Commonwealth agencies can be shown to be completely false.

The next area I would like to touch on is that of industry development. Right from the beginning I have continually maintained the argument that the government's IT outsourcing program is severely damaging the Australian IT&T sector. Why? Because at this point in time every government in the world who is concerned about the economic growth of their particular economy, who is concerned about the future of jobs and who is concerned about what will constitute value in the information society is looking towards information technology and the new technology industries as a source of quality employment and as a source of financial and living standard security for the citizens of their respective countries.

So why is it that this government and Minister Fahey through this IT outsourcing program can almost in one fell swoop undermine Australia's ability? The reason is this: 40 per cent of information technology procurement in Australia can be attributed to government expenditure. That is a far greater proportion than that of many other comparable countries. It is a reflection of our vast geography as much as it is our corporate demographic and not having a huge presence of large companies requiring these types of services.

Secondly, we are on the brink of a burgeoning trade deficit in IT&T or, as recently reported in the Financial Review and I read the headline: `IT imports on the increase'. More than anything else there is a profound economic reason why we need to actively grow our IT&T sector and use policy tools like Commonwealth procurement to make it a reality. The `IT imports on the increase' article articulates and makes direct reference to a published report entitled Information Technology Trade Update that shows that, while Australia's exports are in fact growing, our imports in dollar terms are growing almost exponentially. This article, which was published in the Financial Review on Tuesday, 20 April 1999, confirms a trend identified by Ashley Goldsworthy in a government commissioned report of two years ago which said that unless we arrest this growing IT&T trade deficit Australia is going to be in dire economic straits in terms of our trade deficit. People are spending more money on IT&T as each year passes, and the impact of this particular part of the economy and balance of payments figures will become more and more important as time goes on.

Finally, I would like to say that in all of the government's efforts to try and justify it, there is one thing that keeps coming home to me, and keeps being told to the government, albeit they block their ears. That is the direct impact on small business in this country. We heard again, over two years ago, evidence to a Senate inquiry on IT outsourcing that the government's IT outsourcing program was denying Australian companies the opportunity to participate directly in these government contracts and in doing so they denied them an export credential. That critical export credential, for so many innovative IT&T companies, is having a Commonwealth contract under your belt, so when you go touting for business in the global environment with other governments or with companies overseas, you do so on the basis of having the government's confidence. This sums it up. This is an email I received from a constituent:

Last week I read the article in the Australian detailing your unveiling of the government's practice of hiring contractors from the US to advise the government on its IT outsourcing policies. I would like to support your views that this practice is an absolute disgrace. Further, I am sadly appalled at the government's gross short-sightedness, bull-headedness and ignorance in its IT policies. Spending $A6 million on US experts to advise on where to spend its outsourcing dollars is idiocy, particularly when its own industry is perfectly capable of such expertise, yet struggling badly to meet its IT staffing demands. Local industry needs exactly this kind of work, lest its people seek even more work overseas. I am a 28-year-old Australian, recently returned from abroad, with the greatest of hope and enthusiasm to establish a multi media development firm.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I want to speak today about the abolition of bilingual education in the Northern Territory. I do so a day after the Oxfam report Education Now was released. This is the report that charts the international community's failure to seriously tackle a very important goal of providing a formal education for all children of primary school age by the year 2015. Australia was one of those nations to commit itself to this goal.

speech.para: The report notes that Australia spends most of its education aid budget providing tertiary scholarships. The average cost of a scholarship is $60,000, which is in fact enough to finance 10 primary schools in Zimbabwe, excluding salaries.

The report also criticised the axing of bilingual education in the Northern Territory. The Territory, it said, displayed `flagrant disregard for local languages'. The move was `a clear breach of the government's obligations set out in the Convention on the Rights of the Child to protect and respect the rights of indigenous people'.

Maria Ceresa's excellent piece in the Australian yesterday notes the achievements of the Welsh in retaining their language and the Brazilian government's move to revive hundreds of Indian languages. Their experiences show that it is possible to be proud of minority languages. So I think we ought to ask the question: why is it that Australian governments are so fond of being linguistically backward?

As usual, the Northern Territory was quick to defend its decision, without giving any reasons for it, and the federal government has so far said nothing. As is the custom with most attempts to place Australia's treatment of indigenous people in an international context, the isolationist shutters will no doubt go up: `Outsiders shouldn't be telling us what to do.'

The benefits of bilingual language education have been numerous. Dr Merridy Malin and Stephen Harris, a former principal education officer in the Northern Territory Department of Education, have both listed some of the less obvious but no less tangible benefits: Aboriginal people gain teaching roles and status that would otherwise go to white people; real jobs are created in otherwise job starved Aboriginal communities; many more Aboriginal adults are enrolled in teacher training courses; and there is an important role for schools in recording and teaching Aboriginal culture. However, none of these advantages was addressed by the Territory's education minister in his response yesterday to the Oxfam report. Peter Adamson simply claimed that bilingual education had not achieved `required literacy results in the 17 remote communities in which it existed'.

The minister is quite correct in saying that indigenous children, on average, fall well behind non-indigenous children in English literacy. But it is disingenuous and plainly incorrect to blame this on bilingual education. By phasing out bilingual education, Mr Adamson is essentially throwing the baby out with the bath water. Bilingual education as it now stands has its flaws; I do not think anyone would challenge that. But this does not change the fundamental principle that children have a right to be proficient, both orally and in writing, in their own language.

Evaluating bilingual programs is not easy. What is the catch-up period you allow for students to jump the gap between their first language and English? Who does that evaluation? Is it English teachers or indigenous teachers? Who is in a position to judge how students' first language has helped them to learn English? These are very difficult questions which do not appear to have even been addressed before the Northern Territory government proceeded down this course. What about those schools that have changed models midstream to introduce English earlier, in spite of any lack of evaluation again by the Territory department?

The work of Anne Lowell and Jane Garrutju reveals a host of impediments to the success of bilingual education. They say that the high incidence of middle ear infections means that hearing loss is a serious barrier to oral proficiency in English. Very few teachers in bilingual schools have ESL qualifications. Compulsory ESL qualifications for all non-indigenous teachers working in Aboriginal schools would be an astute move to improving English literacy, one would have thought.

Another barrier is the teacher-student ratios in remote communities, which are as high as one to 55, even though the Territory government recommends a ratio of 1 to 22. I recall that when the education committee visited the Northern Territory and went to Djmada and another remote area school, which was in fact bilingual, we heard that the Northern Territory government funds schools on the basis of average attendances. At the beginning of a term there may be 80 children in a classroom and towards the end of the term that figure comes down towards eight or 10, and the funding is on the basis of the average.

There is only a one-week training course in Darwin for teachers who go out to Aboriginal schools. English is a second language for most children in remote communities. I think we need to recognise that we do not expect newly arrived immigrant children in capital cities in Australia to attain English without receiving targeted help. Why would we expect this of Australian children who are born speaking an Australian language that happens not to be English? For some of these kids English it not just their second language but their third, and sometimes more.

In many communities, English is not used much. It is reserved for teasing, for church and basically for talking with white people. One teacher commented that her students learned far more in a two-week excursion to Melbourne than in the previous two years of classes. This emphasises that in many communities there is little or no need for English in everyday life. I think this is genuinely difficult for us to comprehend if we live in a large capital city or in Canberra or somewhere where there are few Aboriginal people.

Indigenous Australians using their own language should be something to celebrate, I would argue, rather than to condemn because this situation is in fact becoming rarer every year. According to Language Australia, Australian languages are disappearing at the rate of 1½ on average per year. Only about 20 indigenous languages are still passed on to children as the primary language of a community. Only 10 per cent of Aboriginal people speak a traditional language.

Given this backdrop of linguistic loss, Dr Kemp's literacy obsession is intolerable. In parliament and elsewhere, the minister has evaded questions about the federal government's agenda. He has refused to explain why he is not out there defending the teaching of Aboriginal languages. He has refused to explain why he has not uttered a single word of criticism about the abolition of the bilingual education program, and he did not once refer to bilingual education in a recent speech of his about federal indigenous education initiatives—not once. Dr Kemp will not even use the term `bilingual education'. He is not prepared to admit of its existence. He prefers to use the term `literacy', and by that he means English literacy. Dr Kemp has never actually expressed support for the Northern Territory government's move, but his silence, I think, speaks volumes.

Christine Nicholls is a former principal of a bilingual school. She recently wrote that, while Aboriginal children are no longer being separated from their mothers, they are now being separated from their mother tongues—from terra nullius to lingua nullius. Ms Nicholls mentions the experience of the Laja-Manu community. Immediately prior to bilingual education being provided, children were frequently beaten or caned for speaking in Warlpiri. Right now, Aboriginal communities are resisting the Northern Territory government, and I thank Christine Nicholls and Merridy Malin for the following information. The Tiwi staff and community of a Catholic school on Bathurst Island paid for a full-page advertisement in the Northern Territory News, an open letter to the minister. The Warlpiri people at Yuendumu are threatening to keep their children at home. Other communities have issued media releases and complained to the department. Protest banners at Yirrkala claimed, `We won't let you cut off our tongues. Our language is our life.'
They know the stakes are high. Professor Joe Lo Bianco of Language Australia recently explained why the Territory's decision goes to the heart of Aboriginal cultural survival. He said:

Australian language and literacy policy—that does not support the efforts of Aboriginal people to preserve those domains that remain vibrant for indigenous languages—is a limited, assimilationist and defective policy.
He went on:
Such a policy is complicit with cultural damage and dislocation, and with a perverse notion of equality that is premised on schooling making children:
forget what they know
become alienated from their families and backgrounds
and to achieve less than they might.

It was the Whitlam government that originally introduced bilingual education. That was to circumvent fierce ideological opposition from Northern Territory politicians. That same implacable opposition is at work again now in 1999. I do not think we should be letting the federal government off the hook. Dr Kemp, this is a very serious matter, and I think it is time for you to speak up on the question.

talk.start.para: —Today's speech is the fifth in a series of addresses to this chamber I have made on the matter of illicit drug addiction. Some weeks ago I spoke with pride of our government's Tough on Drugs strategy and the significant progress that has already been made in what is the biggest anti-drug program in this country. You may be aware that this undertaking involves essentially a four-pronged strategy over a period of four years: the protection of Australia's borders, fighting drug dealers, educating our children to the dangers of drug use and the zero tolerance of illicit drugs within our school environment, and a renewed commitment to rehabilitation, including custodial rehabilitation for convicted criminals.

speech.para: In a subsequent speech, I also spoke of the community meeting held in my own area of Newcastle where, having anticipated about 80 people turning up, we had 520 people come to a public meeting with their own concerns, being prepared to share with the gathering their own experiences and taking the opportunity to garner advice to help solve their own problems in their own families and to restore some normalcy to their life. There are many instances of what is now becoming a community based approach across the country.

Towards the end of last year, over 600 people gathered at Port Macquarie in a similar way, seeking answers. Within the next week at the University of Newcastle there will be another such community gathering. Just in my own immediate area, the community is coming out and trying to find solutions to this terrible problem that faces our nation. This welling up of community concern at this time is fortunately meeting a proactive government response on a wide front of prevention and rehabilitation.

In another address, I noted that both the Australian Institute of Criminology and the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence confirm that my own state of New South Wales statistically has the highest incidence of criminal activity related to drugs and, indeed, Sydney is the drug capital of Australia. I drew attention to the alarming rate of increase of criminal activity within New South Wales related to drugs and the link between the increased crime rate and drug abuse in New South Wales. I also noted the economic and social commonsense of attacking the drug menace at the supply level and also discussed overseas experience, in particular the successful Swedish model, which essentially employs the principle of a drug free society as a means of showing distinctly and unambiguously that all non-medical use of drugs is unacceptable.

Today I intend to speak about the expansion of the Howard government's Tough on Drugs strategy following the commitment of new moneys totalling almost half a billion dollars to be spent by this government over the next four years to fight the drug menace in our country. A particular focus of the new funding that was announced several weeks ago will be on rehabilitation. Funding benefits have already been received by nearly 150 community organisations. Funding will be directed at these existing services to enhance what they are doing, as well as a number of new initiatives.

People are well aware of the tremendous work being done by voluntary organisations such as the Salvation Army and the Ted Noffs Foundation. What they are probably not as aware of is the enormous amount of work that goes on in community organisations in country towns around Australia that are little known. These groups will be getting a new lifeline of funding to help us undertake a comprehensive program of fighting drugs across Australia.

What is most important is that, no matter what their size, these organisations, often working in a voluntary way, are now part of a total national strategy. Assistance and services will be targeted at particular groups in this approach that the government is now expanding. Children of women in drug treatment, Aboriginals and homeless youth will be a particular focus of this strategy. For example, at my local level in Newcastle in the Hunter there has been approval of funding in the Cessnock area to expand an existing residential rehabilitation service by an additional 20 beds. At Chittaway Bay on the Central Coast a drug rehabilitation program for severe dependence issues amongst Aboriginal people has received funding to help their rehabilitation program.

The expansion of the government's Tough on Drugs strategy has very recently been clarified and been given special impetus by the Australian Council of Governments, which met here in Canberra a short while ago and discussed a national illicit drug strategy. What transpired was the generation of a number of agreed outcomes. Those agreed outcomes between the Commonwealth, the states and the territories may change forever the level of drug abuse in this country. We hope and pray that this united and very powerful initiative by all levels of government will tip the scales in this country in favour of endeavours to reduce the incidence of illicit drugs.

All told, there were six agreed outcomes between the states, territories and the federal government. The heads of government communique spoke of adding a new dimension to the national drug strategy based on a partner ship between governments and the broader community, including voluntary and community organisations. Agreements were made to work together to make a new investment in prevention, early intervention, education and the diversion of drug users to counselling and treatment, along with a major shift in the practice of law enforcement. Most importantly and of major significance, they agreed to work together.

The measures agreed to by the heads of government relate to drugs in schools, drugs in the community, drugs in prison, alternative treatments, drug supply and next steps, in particular partnership agreements which link efforts to combat drug abuse at all the various levels of society. The heads of government clearly stated their opinion that illicit drugs have no place in our schools—a message to be emphatically sent to those who push drugs to school students and students who are drug users. Agreement was given for the Commonwealth provision of resources so that schools will be better able to respond to illicit drug use, to develop a national basis as a means to aid schools and their environment, and the provision of educational and resource materials.

A new nationally consistent approach is to be brought to drug problems faced by the community as governments work together to enable police to divert drug offenders to compulsory assessment. This consistent approach will complement and expand existing state and territory approaches based on such elements as the provision of appropriate law enforcement; the provision of Commonwealth funding for early intervention treatment and ensuring rehabilitation places; shared Commonwealth, state and territory funding for assessment services; and community based services that will provide support for individuals at the conclusion of their treatment.

In relation to prisons, states and territories will develop and fund programs which aim to intercept the supply of drugs to prisons and to develop trial diversionary treatment programs. People should note that the prison population in Australia at the moment is growing and that between 70 per cent and 80 per cent of people who are now in prison are there because of drug related reasons. Support was also given by the heads of government to alternative treatments for drug addiction. The Commonwealth is committed already to the availability of alternative treatments.

This government has indicated its intention to fast-track consideration of the inclusion of naltrexone on the list of prescribed medications available on the pharmaceutical benefits table. Legislative changes at the federal level will be aimed at reducing the supply of illicit drugs within Australia. The Commonwealth will also increase its capacity to intercept drugs coming into the country from overseas supply sources. Lastly, the heads of government agreed to the immediate commencement of joint planning arrangements to combat illicit drug use within Australia via linked partnership agreements at all levels of government in the community.

Areas to be linked will include education, law enforcement and treatment efforts, particularly the development of early intervention programs. In combination, the initiatives agreed to by the heads of government have the potential to deliver enormous benefits to the entire Australian nation by diminishing the extent and the scale of the drug menace that threatens our children. These benefits will come about because of the momentum of a plan which focuses on the key to the whole drug strategy—that is, a plan that focuses on partnerships and involvement at all levels: family, community and government; partnerships between the Commonwealth, states and territories; partnerships between voluntary bodies; partnerships between professional associations; partnerships between government bodies; and the involvement of parents and schools and all levels of the community in general.

I would like to re-emphasise that a response at this level and of this magnitude has never been initiated before in Australia. It is a response which reflects increased government involvement and community concern. It is a response which reflects the determination of our society to work together to move from a reactive to a proactive position in a quest to bring under control the quiet, insidious toll of illicit drug abuse in our Australian community.

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Is the minister aware that for the past year European Union leaders have been considering the reduction of the VAT on certain labour intensive services in order to help boost employment? Does the minister agree that this is recognition that a GST is a tax on jobs? If the European Union recognises that a GST on services such as house painting and renovating, domestic help and aged care and environmental services is a job destroyer, doesn't this argument also apply to the proposed new 10 per cent GST on Australian labour intensive services? If not, why not?
—What an amazing question to get from Senator George Campbell. Senator George Campbell is most famous for a comment that the former leader of the Labor Party, Mr Keating, made about him.
—Boring!

—It is not boring to the people who were affected, Senator. What Mr Keating pointed out was that George Campbell—he was not a senator at that time—wore around his neck 100,000 dead men from the metal trades industry as a result of the policies that he, George Campbell, followed at that time. Now Senator Campbell is in the Senate.
—Madam President, I raise a point of order—
—Oh!

—Why don't you attack the question, not the man? My point of order is on relevance, Madam President. Senator Campbell has asked a perfectly reasonable question of the minister, and he is entitled to a reasonable reply. Attacking the personality of the questioner is inappropriate, particularly from this minister. I ask you to draw his attention to the relevance of his answer.
—I do draw the minister's attention to the question.

—I think my remarks threw into context the person who was posing the question and probably questioned to a degree how committed he was to issues of employment, in view of his past record. What an irony for Senator Cook to say, `Don't play the man.' What is Senator Cook's most famous quote in this parliament? It is true that when Senator Cook leaves the parliament and people ask, `What is Senator Cook remembered for?' they will go to the Hansard of 11 November 1997, I think it was, and they will recall exactly whether Senator Cook plays the man or not.

answer.para: Senator Campbell asked about unemployment. This government has an excellent record in this area. The peak level of unemployment under the Labor Party was about 11.5 per cent. That is the level that unemployment rose to under the Labor Party. So one would question the sincerity of the Labor Party in asking about issues of unemployment. We of course have brought the level down to around 7.4 per cent, and we have an excellent record in job creation. But we wish to go further. One of the reasons that we want to carry out major tax reform is to increase the efficiency of the Australian economy, and there has been a range of models, a number of which were quoted in this parliament this morning in relation to a question from Senator Campbell about the likely effects of tax reform on growth in the economy. We went through four or five models and it is predicted that the tax reform measures this government is proposing will have a very healthy effect on unemployment.

Senator Campbell, I think it is very hard to compare our tax reform measures with the tax system in Europe. They have a large range of taxes. They have various rates and some rates are substantially higher; some in particular areas may be lower. It is very hard to compare. The unemployment levels in this country, from memory, are below the average in Europe already, but this government is determined to go further.

talk.start.para: —It should have been taken up with the European Union.

—Senator Cook has decided to chip in again. I thought that after my earlier remarks you might keep quiet for a few seconds, Senator Cook. This government gives a very high priority to tackling the unemployment problem in this country, and that is one of the reasons that this government is determined to proceed with tax reform.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister also aware that these same European leaders are suggesting that the reduced rate of VAT apply from 1 January 2000 to 31 December 2002? Does the minister support the view that a lower rate of VAT or no VAT at all would be beneficial for labour intensive services and would therefore boost employment?

—One of the means this government uses to reduce the rate of unemployment is to pursue more flexible labour markets, which you and the Labor Party are completely opposed to. One of the issues we have brought before this Senate time and time again is to deal with the unfair dismissals issue in relation to small business. Each time it has been brought forward it has been rejected by the Labor Party. We have a comprehensive program to tackle unemployment, and for Senator Campbell to suggest that the EU is going to remove all VAT is fantasy stuff.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. Australia has been hailed as a miracle economy under the responsible economic management of the Howard government. I ask the minister: will he inform the Senate of new information confirming the underlying strength of the economy? What further measures should be introduced to sustain Australia's strong economic performance?

—I thank Senator Parer for his important question. Yes, it is true that the Australian economy continues to do well under the Howard government. It is not by chance; it is not a miracle. It is because this government took tough but fair decisions— decisions that the previous Labor administration was not prepared to tackle. In particular, the economy is growing at a rate of 4.7 per cent at a time when other economies in the region are experiencing a severe downturn; unemployment is at its lowest level since 1990; home owners are paying the lowest home interest rates in more than 30 years; the share market continues to surge; and business and consumer confidence is up.

answer.para: There has been further confirmation today that the fundamentals of the Australian economy remain strong. Today's consumer price index figures for the March quarter show a headline inflation rate of 1.2 per cent through the year. Whilst this result mainly reflects the impact of the government's 30 per cent tax rebate for private health insurance, the underlying rate of 1.7 per cent confirms continuing low inflation. Underlying inflation has now run at under two per cent for eight consecutive quarters. This government has delivered a low inflation, low interest rate environment which will ensure industry and business continue to grow and to provide job opportunities for unemployed Australians.

The IMF has provided further independent confirmation of the remarkable performance of the Australian economy. The latest IMF World Economic Outlook shows that, despite the impact of the Asian crisis, Australia's growth prospects compare favourably with those of other industrialised economies. In fact, the IMF expects that growth in Australia over 1999-2000 will be higher than the average growth across other advanced economies. The IMF also forecasts that Australia will grow faster than all G7 economies except the US in 1999 and faster than all G7 economies in the year 2000. This conforms with the latest forecast from Westpac which confirms that there is `convincing evidence that the economy has maintained its growth momentum into 1999'. This government has laid the foundations for that growth by bringing the budget back into surplus, by reforming our outdated industrial relations system and by giving our industry and business a low inflation, low interest rate environment.

The next great reform that faces our country, that faces our economy, is of course to reform our outdated taxation system. Australia cannot go into the next century with a tax system that was designed in the 1930s and is now well past its use-by date. I remind you that our new tax package includes $13 billion of personal income tax cuts, the abolition of nine state taxes, major benefits to regional and rural Australia through cheaper transport costs, and guarantees that all Australian exports will be GST free. The ALP wishes to deny the Australian people these benefits—the same ALP that left the economy $10 billion in the red when it went out of government. Labor has it all wrong in relation to economic management. Australia has now the foundations for prosperity in the future. This government should be given the opportunity to go on with the job and give us an up-to-date, properly contemporary, reformed taxation package.

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Is the minister aware that the ACCC has, in its judgment finding the Howard government's private health insurance ads misleading, also expressed the view that `the Trade Practices Act is unlikely to formally apply to government advertisements of this kind'? If the ACCC can act on deceptive ads from shonky used car dealers, why will the government not protect the public from ads run by the Howard government which are just as misleading?

—It seems to me that there was a false premise in the question. I am aware that the ACCC has examined the government's information campaign on the 30 per cent rebate on private health insurance. That was the matter you referred to. I am aware that there was some confusion in the market. For example, the rebate scheme replaced the private health insurance incentive scheme. Some private health insurance policy holders did not receive as great a reduction in premiums as anticipated. But it is very important to point out that, despite the fact that the ACCC did not find that the government's advertising in relation to the rebate breached the Trade Practices Act—it is very important to note that—
—The ads were lies.

—Madam President, Senator Faulkner continues to launch forth with abusive comments. I am providing a detailed answer to the question that Senator Quirke raised. Despite the fact that the ACCC did not find the government's advertising in relation to the rebate breached the Trade Practices Act, this government has moved quickly to avoid confusion about the impact of the rebate scheme. The Department of Health and Aged Care has issued a circular alerting all health funds to the ACCC's concerns and providing advice on ways of minimising the risks of misleading consumers when advertising the new rebate scheme.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given the Howard government's reliance on advertising campaigns in place of sound public policy, and its clear inability to accurately put its case in these ads, should not the Howard government's ads carry a warning for the gullible and naive? When will the government actually tell the Australian people the truth about important matters such as private health insurance?

—I should ignore the abusive preamble to that question. If there is any group that has been shonky in this parliament it is the Labor Party. We can quote numerous examples, but one which involves virtually all the former ministers of the Keating government was the cover-up of the $10 billion black hole in the budget when we came into government. When we came into government, the Labor Party and Senator Cook maintained that the budget was in surplus. There was a $10 billion black hole. There are some shonks in this parliament and they are over there.
—My question is also addressed to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. The hallmark of the Howard government's commendable—

question.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Lightfoot, just a moment. Order!

—Thank you, Madam President. I will start again and try to talk over Senator Forshaw's voice. The hallmark of the Howard government's commendable taxation reform plan is to create a fairer tax system for Australia, part of which includes creating a system that catches tax cheats. Would the Assistant Treasurer inform the Senate as to what measures are being taken by the government to reduce tax avoidance?

—The government does have a plan to reduce taxation avoidance and tackle the so-called black economy. This plan will involve a range of measures and, of course, tax reform is one of the ways that we are tackling the black economy. People who deal in the black economy and flout taxation laws place an unfair and large burden on the rest of the community. The government continues to address this particular problem and we want to make sure that honest, law-abiding Australians are not shouldering the burdens of the black economy.

answer.para: There are strong grounds for arguing that a broad, multistaged indirect tax would increase revenue collected from the proceeds of the black economy. It would mean that income generated through the cash economy had been taxed because the goods and services tax would help catch this money at the point of sale. By totally opposing the government's new tax system, which as we all know features a goods and services tax, the Labor Party are turning a blind eye to the black economy, as they did in the 13 years they were in government in this country. They are turning a blind eye to people who do not participate in the taxation system and who create a greater burden for the average law-abiding Australian.

Under a goods and services tax, people who avoid the current tax system will be forced to participate in the new tax system, typically through the point of sale. This is one of the many advantages of a broad-based indirect tax.
Senator Sherry interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I am indebted to Senator Sherry for calling out. Senator Sherry said in the chamber last week, `The sales tax we have in this country is sustainable and efficient.' That is Senator Sherry's view. Virtually the overwhelming weight of people who would classify themselves as tax experts would not agree with Senator Sherry. Senator Sherry's comments are a huge reflection upon the Labor Party and, frankly, just show how out of touch they are in this debate.

answer.para: The government also plans to introduce one number for each Australian business which will identify them for all government purposes. This is to be known as the Australian business number. The so-called ABN will facilitate the introduction of a single tax compliance statement as well as, amongst other things, streamlining business interaction with the Commonwealth. It will ensure that all bona fide businesses are registered, and that withholding arrangements cover all payments by businesses to people who are not in an identified business. The system will enable the tax office to make significant inroads into the cash economy and therefore create a fairer tax system for all Australians. In fact, the Commissioner of Taxation has estimated that some $3.5 billion over three years in additional income tax revenue will be generated as a result of these collective impacts.

Senator HERRON

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. What we want to know is: will the government guarantee to meet its commitment to these people and ensure that they are refunded the accommodation charge they have paid and that they will no longer have to pay the accommodation charge, as Mr Howard promised these older Australians at the time of the changes?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —As I said previously, Senator Evans has asked this question before. The government will be honouring—and the answer was given to Senator Evans on that—its commitment in full as part of the budget. Where providers have been charging pre 1 October 1997 residents the accommodation charge, these residents will be fully compensated. Senator Evans was told that. Senator Evans was informed in the material that was provided to him. Furthermore, the government will pay providers additional supplements—

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. Senator Herron is misleading the Senate. I have in front of me the Hansard of what he said, and he did not say that at all. He is misleading the Senate and he ought to consider carefully what he is saying.
—There is no point of order.

—I am not attacking what Senator Evans has said. I said that there was supplementary material provided to him, which I understood answered the question that he asked the other day. —My question is addressed to Senator Hill, the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I ask: what representations were made by our Prime Minister, and what undertakings were given by President Habibie, at the Bali talks about disarming the pro-integration militia on East Timor and the removal of the Indonesian defence force from that territory? Given that it is now accepted that ABRI is involved in the arming of the militias, did General Wiranto provide any guarantees that ABRI soldiers in East Timor can now be trusted to fully disarm the militias?

—I think it can be presumed that these matters were discussed and built upon the agreements that were reached in New York at the end of last week. I understand that the agreement in New York includes the absolute neutrality of the Indonesian armed forces during the UN consultation and a role for the Peace and Stability Commission in ensuring the laying down of arms and disarmament efforts. But, yes, ensuring peace and stability during the consultation and autonomy vote process remains the primary responsibility of the Indonesian government. There is no doubt that the Indonesian government, through its President, understands that responsibility and intends to act upon it.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that answer, but he did not answer the question about the disarming of the militias. Were any representations made that he knows of, and were any plans made to do that? We would be very interested in that answer.

—I think all that has been said, and that I should therefore confirm, is that Indonesia accepts its responsibility to ensure that there is a peaceful vote and that people can vote in an environment in which they are not intimidated. That does raise the question of armaments and, as I said, the government of Indonesia has accepted that that matter needs to be resolved in order to ensure that such a peaceful vote can take place.

—My question is addressed to Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Justice. I ask her: is it a fact that the federal government is withholding gun buyback money earmarked for the state of Victoria and accusing that state of watering down national gun laws? Can the minister confirm that the Victorian police minister, Mr Bill McGrath, has stated that he will be referring gun owners to the Commonwealth when Victoria's compensation funds run out? Is it a fact that Mr McGrath informed the minister of this intention and did so some months ago? Given that the Victorian government will not do so, will the federal government compensate firearm owners and dealers who have handed in their weapons?

—I thank Senator Bolkus for that question. The answer to the first question is yes. The answer to the second question is yes. The answer to the third question is: I cannot recall whether Mr McGrath has personally advised me of this, but I have certainly read that view expressed in the paper and attributed to him, and I have not seen it denied. Lastly, as you would well know, Senator Bolkus, as you do read the papers, we have written to state governments that have not complied with the national firearms policy—a policy your party endorses, a policy that all parties in this chamber endorse, to make Australia a safer place. We have written to the states that have more serious compliance problems and have indicated that their failure to comply with the agreement will be taken into account in considering any compensation. The agreement included compensation to be paid through the states, but the prerequisite for that is that the agreement be adhered to. Where there are states that have chosen not to adhere to it, the Commonwealth is entitled to say, `We will take your failure to keep the agreement into account.' We have done that; we have sent them those letters.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the minister further: is the Commonwealth satisfied that the Victorian government has met its obligations under the agreement struck between state and territory governments post Port Arthur? I take into account that you have written to them, but I do ask: what further action will the Commonwealth take to ensure that Victoria does comply with the agreement on national gun laws? Minister, why didn't the Prime Minister raise this issue at the recent Premiers Conference, as he promised the Australian public on A Current Affair just a few weeks before that conference?

—Senator Bolkus, as I understood your question, it was: has Victoria met its commitments under the national firearms policy? The answer to that I thought was—and this was in the answer to the question you first asked—clearly, no, they have not met their commitments. As to why the Prime Minister does not raise something at a premiers meeting, I will refer that matter to the Prime Minister. I recall that the first time the Prime Minister wanted to discuss this matter the premiers walked out in a huff, which is what has occasioned us to resort to saying to the premiers, or to their states at least, that if they do not comply we will have to take into account their failure to comply in considering whether we will then comply with the agreement and forward the compensation.

answer.para: Senator Bolkus, it cannot be underlined strongly enough that the Prime Minister and this government are 100 per cent behind the national firearms policy. The Prime Minister has said on a number of occasions—and I will repeat it for your benefit now—we will do anything in our power to ensure that agreement is adhered to. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Senator Vanstone. Given the deteriorating human rights situation in East Timor and given the government's current policy of not accepting people fleeing from East Timor as eligible for refugee status in Australia, what intentions does the government have in relation to East Timorese people arriving at Australia's borders seeking refugee status in this country?

—I thank the senator for her question. She was kind enough to give my office some notice of this question, and I have contacted the minister for immigration to see whether I can get the latest possible update on the situation—because, as you would understand, Madam President, the senator's question is premised on the basis that there will be some change. She identifies the current situation, and asks whether there is to be a change. The advice I have from the minister's office is that he would prefer that question to be taken on notice. He has not yet had the opportunity to discuss the situation in Timor with the Prime Minister, with Alexander Downer and with Defence Minister Moore as a consequence of their recent trip.

answer.para: I am obviously not privy to the full range of discussions that have been had on that trip. The minister's office has asked me to indicate that they will reply to you as promptly as they possibly can but do not want to do that without the benefit of a briefing on the recent trip of the Prime Minister.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question, and I thank the minister for that answer. Can the minister guarantee that East Timorese fleeing the territory will not automatically be detained or deported on arrival in Australia if they have inappropriate documentation? What plans does the Australian government have to facilitate the processing of visa applications in East Timor for those seeking protection in Australia, given the need for an expedited process? I realise that, similar to your first answer, a portion of that question at least will be on notice.

—Madam President, as the senator realises, this is a somewhat fluid situation. I will accept the undertaking of the office of the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs that they will give you a reply as quickly as they can on any changes, including those that follow on from your supplementary question.

—My question is also directed to the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator Vanstone. Can the minister confirm that two international experts have recently described Victoria's heroin problem as the worst in the world? Is it a fact that Dr Franz Trautmann stated, `I have never seen a heroin death rate like this anywhere in the world,' and `Nothing compares to the heroin epidemic in Victoria'? Can the minister confirm that the research by Dr Trautmann and Dr Robert Haemmig reveals that, `Victoria probably has the worst heroin death rate in the world per head of population'? Can the minister inform the Senate as to whether this epidemic in heroin use in Victoria is the result of poor gateway interdiction procedures or a consequence of inadequate local policing procedures?

—I thank the senator for his question. Senator, if I have seen that research, the names of the researchers do not come to mind. I will check that out and come back to you with some detail on that. As to the general question of heroin use, it is recognised that there is a serious problem in Victoria. There is a serious problem in New South Wales, as you well know. What I was pleased to note vis-a-vis Victoria is the high rate of arrest of heroin dealers compared with the rate of arrest of heroin dealers in New South Wales. If you want to ask about what I know about local policing matters, I know only that which I can glean from reports that are prepared. The figures that I provided to the Senate last time this matter was raised—in fact, by me—clearly indicated that Victoria was putting a significant effort into policing this matter.

answer.para: Victoria has some innovative approaches. In one area of Victoria they are trialling a new response by police which basically gives police at the local level the capacity to say to first-time offenders in relation to serious drugs that they have a choice of either going into a program to assist them with their drug problem or facing prosecution. I am very interested in trials such as that because anything that can be done to save any individual from a conviction of any sort of criminal matter, particularly one relating to drugs, in my view is a program that is likely to lead to that person having a greater chance of not, at a later stage in their life, having what would then be their first conviction. So the earlier the intervention the better.

New South Wales is also trialling some innovative approaches. One in particular is the question of drug courts. You may know that there is a conference in relation to drug use in Adelaide this week, covering some four days. Marilyn Roberts from the US Department of Justice will be speaking at that conference about drug courts. One matter that might be borne in mind by everybody who presumes to have an interest in this matter is that drug courts, as I am advised by Ms Roberts, started in the US not at some Commonwealth or state level initiative of policy makers but by judges realising the power they have when they can make orders. Judges have quite extensive power. It is a matter of interest the degree to which a number of courts in Australia could behave as drug courts were the treatment facilities available at the state level, which is a matter largely for the states.

In summary, I do not think you can pick one state over the other. They both have a serious problem. They both are trying their levels of local policing. I have quoted figures that indicate Victoria is arresting more dealers, trying to get at the dealer rather than the user. The last part of your question was: is this some problem with interdiction at the gateway? Senator, I am embarrassed for you that you are silly enough to ask that question when you know that, under this government, interdiction at the airport has far exceeded, in some cases by four and five times, the annual average that was ever achieved under your government.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the government be reconsidering its opposition to heroin trials in the light of the member for Bradfield's plea to do so yesterday?

—I have not heard the comments yesterday by the member for Bradfield, described by the senator as a `plea', but I would be extremely surprised if this government was prepared to reconsider that. It is about time that people who want to dabble in this debate to get themselves a bit of publicity did a bit of reading up first. Premier Carr, a Labor Premier, acknowledged that heroin trials are not the way to go. The maximum number you could put through a heroin trial is nothing like the number of heroin addicts he has. Let us not pretend that this one-off solution that we can raise every now and then—toss it in, give Senator Faulkner a bit of limelight—is a good idea, because it is not.

—My question without notice is to Senator Newman, the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. What plans does the government have to address the longstanding and well-known deficiency with regard to fast sea lift logistics support for elements of the ADF?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I thank senator MacGibbon. We all know of his long-standing involvement in defence matters. It is a pity that this matter of national importance is not given more airing in this chamber by other parties. The Minister for Defence announced on Sunday that Australia's Defence Force capability will be boosted by the introduction of a Tasmanian built, high speed catamaran to provide additional sea transport support for ADF activities in northern Australia.

answer.para: I am advised that Defence has commenced negotiations with International Catamarans, Incat, the Tasmanian builder and supplier of the vessel, to charter the catamaran for a two-year period. This kind of vessel has significant advantages in terms of its capabilities and its flexibility. With a top speed of around 40 knots, the catamaran can carry up to 500 fully equipped troops plus stores and vehicles. Its introduction will complement Australia's ability to move troops and equipment in the most effective matter, and it will support the recently announced increased levels of preparedness for our troops.

The new vessel will participate in a range of ADF exercises including Crocodile 99 later this year. I am advised that there is also scope to use it in the provision of support for disaster relief operations within Australia. I understand that it will be based in Darwin from the end of June this year and commissioned into naval service with two crews—
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senators on my left will cease interjecting.

—I presume they are not Tasmanian senators, Madam President. It is important to Tasmanians. The catamaran will be commissioned into naval service with two crews of 20 Navy and Army personnel. Training of the crews will be conducted at the Australian Maritime College in Launceston. This charter represents a further investment by Defence in Australian industry and technology—something which the previous government said was important to the future of our defence capability. It increases the operational effectiveness of the ADF and it boosts linkages between the Defence Force and local industry. This support for Tasmanian industry will mean more money and more jobs for my state. I know that my colleague Senator Abetz, who is the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence, is particularly pleased by his department's plans, as are all my Tasmanian colleagues on this side of the chamber.

answer.para: Australia is internationally renowned for advances in the development of this type of vessel and it offers an innovative solution to current defence requirements. This is the first time that the ADF has diverged from conventional hull forms for its major fleet units. Both the United States and the British navy are also considering the multihull concept for sea transport operations. This contract with the Australian Defence Force could provide an opportunity for some collaboration with our allies which may possibly lead to more orders for Incat—and surely all Australians would be glad to see that growth in an innovative and technologically advanced area of Australian industry.

talk.start.para: —My question without notice is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General, Senator Vanstone. Is the Minister aware of comments by Chief Justice Alistair Nicholson of the Family Court last week when he blamed federal government cuts to legal aid for a legal aid drought? Is it a fact that the Chief Justice said that, as a result of the cuts to legal aid, `those to whom aid is denied must either abandon a course of action or remain unrepresented and that in this equation no account is given to the children.' Can the Minister confirm that, based on a survey quoted by the Chief Justice, 35 per cent of family law cases will now run with at least one party unrepresented by a lawyer and that this figure will increase due to the ongoing impact of cuts to legal aid? Can the Minister advise the Senate what the rate of unrepresented actions were prior to the government slashing the legal aid budget?

—I thank the senator for his question. Nothing Justice Nicholson said would be a surprise to me. I do not know why you bother to phrase a question asking me what the Chief Justice of the Family Court said when you apparently have a direct quote of what he said. It seems to be a non-sequitur question. I take your general interest and long-standing interest in legal aid funding and will respond to that question in that general sense. I will go back and look at the comments that Justice Nicholson has made and see whether there is anything specific to your question. If the Attorney thinks there is anything to add, he no doubt will. But understand this: the funding provided by the Commonwealth for legal aid this financial year is based on the level of funding for Commonwealth matters for 1995-96. This was agreed with all states and territories prior to the implementation of the new agreements. Funding for Commonwealth matters has been preserved and the subsidy for state and territory matters of $33.158 million per year has been removed.

answer.para: That is the rub with the argument here. The government has said that it will fund Commonwealth legal aid matters and that it is up to the states to fund state matters. What the commissions are doing with the allocation of their funding after that may be a matter of dispute, but that is what this government has decided to do. Let me repeat that the funding provided by the Commonwealth for legal aid this financial year is based on the level for Commonwealth matters for 1995-96. Under the current legal aid funding arrangements, the government is of the view that there is sufficient funding available for family law matters. The focus has shifted away from funding costly criminal law matters—which tend to arise under state law—at the expense of family law matters. Consequently, the quarantining of Commonwealth legal aid dollars means that family law is no longer subsidising criminal law.

Family law matters, and especially matters relating to children, are a key priority area for this government. Protecting the safety of a child or spouse who is at risk is to be accorded the highest priority in making grants of aid in family law. Each agreement between a legal aid commission and the Commonwealth states that protecting the safety of a child or spouse who is at risk is to be accorded the highest priority in making grants of aid in family law. The latest data we have from legal aid commissions indicates that nationally there has been no significant change in approval rates for legal aid in family law in the four-year period 1994-95 to 1997-98. As I said, if you want answers to any more detailed questions, and I think there were one or two, they may require us to seek statistics from the Family Court.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Thank you, Minister. You have indicated that you will come back to me with the rate of unrepresented actions prior to the government's slashing of the legal aid budget. Further, I ask you: will you finally concede the obvious point that cuts to legal aid of up to $232 million are the cause of the legal aid drought, or will you continue to persist with the fatuous spin that people just do not want to have legal representation when they present to the Family Court on matters of life changing significance to them?
—Senator, let me see if I can go back to what I have indicated to you and repeat the words. What was properly described as `the subsidy to the states' has now ended. Here we are:

answer.para: Funding for Commonwealth matters has been preserved—
that is, the Commonwealth is providing funding for Commonwealth matters—
and—
as I said to you before—
the subsidy for State and Territory matters of $33.158 million has been removed.

If you want to argue the case that, in the far distant future—if you people ever manage to scramble back into government with the pathetic record that you had—you will reinstate funding to the states and pay for all their legal aid, I look forward to Mr Beazley making that commitment.

talk.start.para: —Senator, your remarks should be addressed to the chair.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. What is the minister's response to the Oxfam report released yesterday which strongly criticised the government and the Northern Territory government for its decision to abolish bilingual education in Aboriginal languages? Do you agree with Oxfam that this shows `a flagrant disregard for local languages'? How does the minister reconcile the federal government's silence on the issue with Australia's commitment to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child? Is the minister aware that Aboriginal languages are disappearing at the rate of 1½ every year? And if English literacy is of such concern to this government, why is it that the Northern Territory can provide no qualified ESL teachers to most of the schools in remote communities that once had bilingual education?

—Can I say at the outset that this government has a good record in relation to indigenous education. I further say that in relation to matters of indigenous education and the Northern Territory government I suggest that Senator Allison direct her question to the Northern Territory government. On the part of the federal government, the coalition has made a big commitment to improving the educational achievements of indigenous students. It has done this by increasing funding by more than $50 million across the education portfolio over the levels of Labor's last year in government—an estimated $333.8 million in 1998-99. That funding takes into account higher education support, the VET sector, the Indigenous Education Direct Assistance Program and the Indigenous Education Strategy Initiatives Program. This government has tied spending to outcomes in our education programs by establishing performance targets and reporting to measure educational progress and achievement. Gone are the days of just throwing money at a problem and hoping it will go away; we are looking at outcomes and funding—those outcomes which will practical benefits to indigenous students and indigenous people in this country.

answer.para: The government is also seeking to identify best practice education in order to lift indigenous educational achievements. We have a range of strategic results projects—SRPs—which focus on student retention, literacy, numeracy, vocational education and training, and also some capital projects. This funding involves a total of $35 million and really addresses some of those areas of concern in relation to indigenous education. It also has introduced intensive English as a second language assistance for indigenous language speaking students from the NESB communities commencing in primary school for the first time. In 1998-99 that will total $7.4 million per annum. This government is totally committed to improving the educational outcomes for indigenous students.

talk.start.para: —What about Aboriginal languages? That is the question.

—It has addressed this across the board. And I might say to Senator Brown that instead of interjecting he might want to go to visit some of the communities, visit places I have been to like Notre Dame and Batchelor College in the Northern Territory, and see the practical benefits that are being delivered on the ground to indigenous Australia. Whilst we are doing much to help indigenous Australia, much still has to be done, and the government acknowledges that. But at least we are on the job and we are addressing the problem.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer and ask: since he is measuring educational outcomes, will they be in Aboriginal languages, and does the government condone the fact that the Territory took this decision without consultation and without educational justification? Did the minister discuss the matter with the Territory? Was the abolition of bilingual education mentioned in the Territory's literacy plan? And why did the minister not use literacy funding to stop the Territory pursuing its assimilationist and destructive policies?

—As I stated at the outset, the Northern Territory government is one which governs its own affairs and those sorts of questions should be addressed to the Northern Territory government. The Commonwealth government works in cooperation with the governments of the states and territories but it is not the policy of the government to be telling other governments what to do in relation to educational policies. What we are doing is addressing policies that are directly under Commonwealth control to benefit indigenous students in this country.

—My question is directed to the minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, Senator Macdonald. Can the minister advise if the Department of Transport and Regional Services has undertaken any modelling on the effects of the proposed open skies policy on regional Australia? Is the minister aware of the comments made by Qantas chief executive James Strong that allowing foreign carriers to carry domestic passengers within Australia will lead to a rationalisation of regional air services—meaning cuts? Can the minister advise which other comparable countries around the world allow foreign carriers to carry domestic passengers on any route they choose? For example, does the United States allow Qantas unfettered access to domestic routes?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Mackay for at last recognising me and asking me a question. I was feeling rather lonely here. I do appreciate the question. I suspect there are few countries that allow international airlines internal rights to carry. I think Senator Mackay mentioned particularly the United States, and I think she knows that the answer to that is no, they do not allow Qantas to fly internally. I am not personally aware of what modelling the department has done, but I shall refer that to Mr Anderson to see whether he has anything to add.

answer.para: I do appreciate Senator Mackay raising the question about the impact on regional services should an open skies policy allow commercial airlines from other countries into Australia. Both Qantas and Ansett have used regional air services as a threat to run a commercial argument on the open skies policy. I think it is quite legitimate for Qantas and Ansett to run whatever commercial arguments they want to to support their argument opposing an open skies policy for internal flights within Australia. What I do object to with those two airlines, and I have made my concerns known to both of them, is that they use services to regional Australians as a threat to support their wider commercial arguments. I am quite annoyed at regional Australians being used as pawns in a commercial argument by two multinational companies which do provide other domestic services in Australia.

I do concede that both airlines and their subsidiaries, associates and affiliates do currently provide a reasonably good service to those of us in regional Australia, although I must say they must think those of us in regional Australia do not eat much. Senator Ray, you are lucky you do not come from regional Australia, because those of us from regional Australia seem to have to be able to squeeze into much smaller seats than the lucky people who happen to live in the capital cities. But they do provide a reasonable service to regional Australia. I understand also from my research that the services that they provide to regional Australia are profitable. In fact, I cannot understand why Qantas would continue to run Southern, Eastern, Sunstate and Airlink if they were not profitable. They are in fact feeder services more than regional services and Qantas does benefit from those. I think they run them profitably. To use those airlines as a threat for a more major commercial argument is poor, and I have told the companies that myself. In relation to Ansett's affiliate Flight West, up my way, I must say that they do conduct a very good operation. They obviously do it profitably because they are still in business.

talk.start.para: —This is a fully paid commercial, is it?

—I have been given the opportunity and I do want to give credit to those smaller airlines for providing for those of us in regional areas. Very often we are the forgotten Australians. We were particularly under your government, Senator. But under our government, of course, regional Australians are getting services equal to other Australians. I do thank Senator Mackay for allowing me to raise that. We are appreciative of the commercial services that are available, but I do not really like and I do not think it is appropriate for the major domestic carriers to use the regional airlines as a threat. (Time expired)
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the minister therefore reject the assertion that the open skies policy will result in a diminution of service to regional Australia?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —You obviously did not listen, Senator. You had written out your supplementary before you had heard the answer. I simply say again that there is a service that is provided. Apparently those services are profitable. Apparently they would continue no matter what happens to Qantas and Ansett on the major domestic routes. If you have information that is to the contrary, I would be pleased to see it. But both of them are private companies and I do not have access to their internal documents. They are not government run any more—
—Thanks to Labor.
—Thanks to Labor, yes. Labor privatised Qantas, and good luck to them for doing it.
—With the support of the Left in Tasmania.
—With the support of the Left in Tasmania. We do not have immediate access to their documents, but I assume they are operating profitably. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. Is the minister aware of concerns within the arts community over the issue of authenticity in the $150 million a year Aboriginal art industry? Will the minister inform the Senate of what steps have been taken to address the serious allegations made by artists and dealers concerning the faking of Aboriginal art?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —There might be some on the other side of the chamber who do not have a particular interest in this matter, but I do. I have been to a number of these communities and I have a modest collection of Aboriginal art, so I have followed the debate very closely. The concerns that I think are being aired at the moment are ones that are very serious indeed, and it would be a great shame if people were intimidated into silence because of fear that somehow they might adversely affect the interests of some of the most disadvantaged people in Australian society.

answer.para: There are a number of absolutely first-class and indeed sometimes world-class Aboriginal artists, some recently passed away and some still living. In the last 25 years Western Desert dot art has become something of which Australia has been very proud and has also been a source of a great level of income for many remote Aboriginal communities. So it is particularly important in those circumstances that the integrity of the industry is upheld and that the spotlight is shone on any shonky practices.
