I do commend Susan McCulloch in particular for injecting some fresh air into some fairly dirty linen that has been evident in recent times.

Many people travel to the outback. Many people purchase indigenous art both in the cities and in the rural areas. Again, it is particularly important that they know what they buy and that people are not guilty of misrepresentation. What is particularly of concern is a recent practice that has been described as `reworking' whereby a very well known artist might have relatives who do the first so-called draft and then the artist himself comes in, basically signs off on the work and then it is passed off as a work of that artist.

talk.start.para: —How do you know that?

—It is not new, as I am sure everyone will acknowledge, that you can have community contribution into works of art and throughout the century we have had collaboration on works. What is critically important, however, is that they not be passed off as something that they are not. So, where you have a very senior artist—a very well recognised artist—if that artist simply signs his name to a work of someone else, then it is not his work. Those who purchase it in good faith have been misled and that sort of passing off action should not be tolerated. I have no doubt that all responsible dealers and people involved in the industry will want to ensure that these sorts of practices do not continue.

answer.para: So it is, I think, a very big step forward that Art.Trade—in association with 43 Aboriginal art galleries, art centres and consultants—has been set up and I commend in particular Adrian Newstead for his drive and commitment to the cause in founding such an organisation. It is also very important that ATSIC and the Australia Council have provided funding to the National Indigenous Arts Advocacy Group towards the establishment of a national authenticity label. There will be a very important conference in Cairns later this year to address these issues.

I hope that what will emerge from these very constructive efforts within the industry is a practice that will ensure that people do feel confident when they go and buy works of art, that they do know what they are buying, that they are not misled or find that works have been misrepresented and that they do have the sense of pride that I think all Australians derive from seeing the success of people like Emily Kame Kngwarreye and many other leading Australian Aboriginal ar tists. I simply say to the Senate that it is appropriate that we are having this debate and that we should welcome it as, I think, a very important step forward in ensuring that this industry goes from strength to strength.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Yesterday Senator Stott Despoja asked me a question about genetically engineered foods and I told her that if there was any further information available I would get back to her. I would like to incorporate that answer in Hansard . I have already given her a copy.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
QUESTION WITHOUT NOTICE
SENATOR STOTT DESPOJA- 27 APRIL 1999
GENETICALLY MODIFIED FOODS

para.inline: SENATOR STOTT DESPOJA—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. I am glad to hear that he is concerned that unsafe genetically modified products would not be available for sale in Australia. But I reiterate my question in relation to international standards. I would like the minister to confirm for us whether or not acceptance or approval of a genetically modified food overseas will be accepted as the sole basis for approval for sale of that product in Australia. Could you clarify if that will be specifically one of the criteria that will be allowed under the A18 standards that will be put forward by ANZFA?

speech.para: SENATOR HERRON—I can confirm that all foods produced using gene technology must undergo ANZFA's own safety assessment before they can be approved for sale in Australia. This will be required by the new standard for genetically modified foods (Standard A18).

ANZFA's own safety assessment is rigorous and takes into account not only the dietary intake, the nutritional composition, and the potential toxicity and allergenicity of the food, but also considers the nature of the genes introduced and their function and effect in the modified organism.

Clearly, ANZFA would be in breach of good practice if it did not take into account the approval status overseas of a food but such information is not of ultimate significance to ANZFA's own safety assessment.

In order to fully outline the criteria which ANZFA employs in assessing the safety of genetically modified foods, I am arranging for a copy of the Guidelines for the safety assessment of foods to be included in Standard A18 to be sent to the Senator's office.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I have some further responses to a question asked of me by Senator Bourne in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the question having been asked on 30 March. I seek leave to have those incorporated.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
Senate Question
Australian representations to the Indonesian government and military on the arming of East Timorese residents
Senator Bourne asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Hill, on 30 March 1999:

1. Does the Minister agree that for Australia to have a peaceful neighbour in East Timor it is essential that the so-called resistance groups on East Timor be disarmed and that ABRI be discouraged from arming any more East Timorese residents?

2. What action is the government taking to encourage Indonesia to disarm these groups, both at a diplomatic level with the Indonesian government and at high military level with the Indonesian defence force?

3. (supplementary question) Could the Minister find out for the Senate the answer to part two of my question about whether the ADF has had any discussions with the Indonesian defence force, with ABRI, about this, and what sort of response we have had? Also could the Minister find out what sort of response the Australian Government has had from the Indonesian government?
Senator Hill—The answer to the Senator's question is as follows:
1. Senator Hill answered the first question.

2. Senator Hill answered the second question, with the exception of specifically addressing high level representations by the Australian Defence Force to the Indonesian defence force (see response at question 3).

3. The Australian Defence Force has registered the Australian Government's concerns over the presence of armed civil militias in East Timor consistently and at the highest levels with Indonesian military leaders both in Jakarta and East Timor. Commander of the Defence Forces Admiral Barrie discussed this issue with his Indonesian counterpart General Wiranto on 11 March. The Army Attache also raised this issue during his visit to East Timor 14-18 March.

The Indonesian authorities have said they have not provided weapons to civil militia groups in East Timor but have provided weapons to ABRI-trained auxiliary forces (wanra), as elsewhere in Indonesia.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask Senator Hill, the Minister representing the Minister for Trade, in accordance with the provisions of standing order 74(5) for an explanation for his failure to answer question on notice No. 306, placed on notice on 30 November 1998, to do with the entertainment expenses of the Deputy Prime Minister, Minister for Trade and honoured guest in the chamber here today. Welcome.

—I am sure that my answer, when it is tabled, will indicate that they are modest in the extreme. Why they have not been tabled is possibly because they are so modest. I have now been told that they have been tabled.
—No, they haven't. I haven't received them.

—Madam President, I ask Senator Alston, the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, in accordance with the provisions of standing order 74(5) for an explanation of his failure to answer question on notice No. 310, placed on notice on 30 November 1998.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I am advised that Senator Robert Ray did in fact contact my office, presumably this morning, but because I did not get back to the office until fairly close to starting time I was not made aware of that and I therefore have not had the opportunity to pursue the matter. But I do understand that the answers are likely to be forthcoming tomorrow.
—Under standing order No. 74(5)(b), I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the Ministers' responses.

Could I start by thanking Senator Newman, who was able to get me this answer today. I point out it is 146 days since the question was asked and I did receive an answer from the Department of Veterans' Affairs just today. Then, coincidentally, I received two answers from Senator Ian Macdonald—not complete answers but at least an attempt to answer those questions today. I appreciate Senator Macdonald's efforts. But I have to say that the Department of Transport and Regional Services has given a disgraceful answer. It has omitted certain material, a theme I will return to in a moment. That leaves us with two unanswered questions. I have a feeling that the one concerning the Deputy Prime Minister is floating around, and I will probably have it by the end of the day—and Senator Hill tells us it is modest. But I have to say, Deputy Prime Minister—I am not addressing you directly—you should at least have a good look at some of the other answers that have been provided. They ain't modest.

talk.start.para: —Senator Ray, you should be addressing your remarks to the chair, not the gallery.

—I did say I was doing that, but I was probably trying to save on a stamp, Madam President, and just send a message through very directly. We have had an explanation from Senator Hill and Senator Alston today. Senator Alston has not had time to chase it up. He will, and Senator Hill thinks the question will be answered today. But let me tell Senator Hill why these questions have not been answered after 146 days. Let me tell Senator Hill that these answers were deliberately held up, not by the representative ministers here today but by the political apparatus in the Prime Minister's office. Let me tell Senator Hill that there was a meeting of the chiefs of staff in late March to consider these five questions on notice. They were discussed at length at that meeting. Then a direction was sent out to each of the department secretaries via the chief of staff in each of the offices as to how these questions were to be answered. That direction said, `You will not answer the question asked. You will withhold certain information as to the individuals concerned that were subject to entertainment by ministers.'

speech.para: You cannot have it both ways. If it is official entertainment, the public has a right to know who is being officially entertained. If it is private entertainment, the public has a right to know that the ministers have paid for it themselves and are not relying on the taxpayer to pay for those particular ones. You might wonder why we asked only the National Party ministers. Because previous experience has told us that they are the ones who get their snouts in the trough, first up and biggest. If anyone in the chamber does not believe me, just have a look at the Department of Transport and Regional Services over a 2½-year period: their total expenditure on ministerial entertainment was $27,613—just for that one department.

One has to acknowledge, though, that there is legitimate entertainment. If there is a visiting minister—even a visiting state minister—or officials on a particular board, the minister should be able to say, `I should be able to go out and entertain those people and charge the department.' But look at the answers as they come in: for instance, Minister Scott goes off with a journalist to the Ottoman Restaurant and sticks the taxpayer with a bill of $120. Time and time again that is there. Minister Vaile goes off to X restaurant. These answers are the Australian good food guide. That is what they are. Two of them wander over to the Commonwealth Club and the taxpayer gets hit with $314.

The point is that there are probably three areas of entertainment here. First, official, of which there is no doubt, run by SERHOS or approved by the secretary to the department—that is the normal thing. Then there is the twilight zone, where you as a minister might say, `These people have come to visit me and I need to entertain them.' And then there is the rort zone, where basically you are organising to take ministerial staff out to dinner and stick the taxpayer with it. That is what has been happening.

talk.start.para: —You never did it?
—Never. Never, ever, ever did I take out ministerial or departmental staff and stick the taxpayer.
—Richo never did it.
—Senator Alston interjects out of his seat.
—Order! Senator Alston, you are out of your seat and it is disorderly to be behaving as you are.
—Senator Faulkner, you are also out of order by shouting.

—Senator Alston has the cheek to criticise Senator Richardson, when he was deputy leader, whose travel allowance claims always came in $10,000 below Senator Alston's. So, unless you have some evidence, Senator Alston, do not go on about this. I wonder whether there are two rules in this coalition government—Liberal ministers expected to behave with propriety and modesty and their National Party colleagues with no controls at all. We have already seen in terms of aircraft charter that they average about $60,000 a year compared with the Liberals' $6,000 a year. I just cannot believe some of these entertainment expenses that have been approved. They will be in Hansard , so I will not bore you by reading all the detail. So far Mr Sharp, departed, Mr Vaile and Mr Scott have a lot to answer for, in my view.

speech.para: But what this government are really going to have to answer for is the cover-up. I want them to respond at some stage and deny that the chiefs of staff got together and colluded to delete the names. When the first question was asked of the department of transport all the names of the guests were listed out. A lot of people in the list, of course, have the bottom out of their pants—Richard Pratt, Dick Smith, all the crew are here being paid for by the taxpayer. But, in fairness, I think they qualify because these functions were either official or semi-official and are fairly kosher. But, in going through all these examples, let us just take lunch of 3 July 1997. That involved three persons including John Sharp and media representatives. Eduardo's Restaurant, Noosa—do you recognise that one, Senator Alston? I bet you do. That was $276.80. I bet you have been up there a few times to open art shows. And on it goes. The Hyatt Hotel, the Well Club, the Japanese Garden, Cowra, the Poseidon Cafe, Park Royal Hotel. They have breakfast for staff.

You have to draw a distinction somewhere between what is official and what is not official. Once you do that there is no reason whatsoever that the names of the people attending these functions could not be published. I would not have been ashamed to have any of my official guests who attended official dinners named as individuals. But if in fact it is a sort of conspiracy meeting and you are embarrassed, that is fine, but do not get the taxpayers to pay for it. We are anxious to see the final figures for Mr Anderson and Mr Fischer. They may show a pattern that is completely different from that of the other National Party ministers. The oversight of not asking about Mr McGauran's past will be quickly overcome this afternoon by yet another question on notice.

In conclusion, Senator Hill and Senator Alston, through inadvertence and lack of information, have not given an accurate answer to the Senate as to why these questions have been delayed. They do not know. I accept that. I accept that they probably did not know that there was some sort of conspiracy amongst the chiefs of staff and ministers' offices to delay the production of these answers until stimulated today. I accept that they did not know. But I do not think it is good enough for chiefs of staff to direct departmental secretaries as to what they will allow to be published and what they will not allow to be published.

The warning I put out now is that that instruction cannot go to freedom of information. If someone goes to FOI these documents, they are going to have to provide the names of individuals because they cannot direct the FOI officer. It has been past practice to publish those names. But do not ask us to go that route. The departments hate FOI. Because of the expense of third party checking, they are encouraging us to put questions on notice—and we are entitled to answers.

I do not insist on the 30-day rule. For heaven's sake, it was 146 days before I got up on this. I have another 80 questions overdue by more than 30 days. I will not get up and whinge about it. I know how hard it is to answer some of these questions, and it is not really that exciting whether you get the answer after 30 days or 60 days or 90 days. But in this case the answers were deliberately held up because they were politically embarrassing. The answers have been doctored by political interference in directing departmental secretaries on which way to react.

The answers themselves show an absolutely unmitigated degree of greed by National Party ministers, who have their snouts in the trough well and truly. The results of their departmental secretaries paying for some of these entertainments I find unbelievable and of enormous value to the ministers concerned.

I will finish on this point: it should be remembered that within the ministerial payroll there is a component for entertainment—from memory, it is about $10,000 a year. It used to be separately listed but because it became fully taxable after 1985 it was rolled into salary in the late 1980s. Nevertheless, it is there for that purpose. I do not know the payroll consequences of it with this coalition government because of the distinction between junior ministers and cabinet ministers—there are differential pay rates—but the entertainment component is there, and it is there to be used.

I am certain Senator Ian Macdonald would never think of taking his staff out to lunch and sticking it with the taxpayer. I am sure he would not. I am sure he has thought about it but thought, `That's just not on,' and I am sure a majority of his colleagues have thought that. But not so the good old boys from the National Party. They have snouts bigger than aardvarks—if it moves, they will snort it up. If there is a chance to maximise, they will maximise, and they will do it all at the taxpayers' expense and, in the end, they bring all of us into disregard. I do hope that, having got these answers, someone in government—maybe even these famous chiefs of staff—will go back and, instead of writing guidelines for departmental secretaries on the way they answer questions, they will write guidelines for behaviour of ministers, especially National Party ministers, so they will behave themselves in future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Justice and Customs (Senator Vanstone) to questions without notice asked today.

I say at the start that this is a very hard act to follow. In question time today I think we had for the first time the official acknowledgment by this government that the national gun laws are no longer national. For the first time, we found out that one particular state, Victoria, is not meeting its obligations, and for the first time we have discovered that the national gun buyback scheme has collapsed because of what is happening in Victoria.

Basically, the Victorian state government is not prepared to buy back guns—it is not prepared to meet the bill. It seems, from the answers given today by the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator Vanstone, that the federal government does not have a contingency plan to pick up the ball. We are concerned because the national gun laws were implemented in response to the events at Port Arthur which took place three years ago this week.

For some time now, the opposition has been concerned that the government, especially ministers Vanstone and Williams, have basically dropped the ball by not ensuring that across the country there is national uniformity in the implementation of the gun buyback scheme. Victoria is now a real problem for the national gun buyback scheme, but there has been concern for some time that the scheme was not operating in full consistency across the country.

The submission today comes after more than just some months of inaction by federal government ministers. We have been concerned that ministers Vanstone and Williams have not been pursuing this matter in a way that they should have been. The implementation problems are not just today's. In a sense they stretch back to April 1997 when the government first received a secret report, which the opposition parties ensured was tabled in this place in May 1998. The report made it very clear that there were major discrepancies in the implementation of the national gun buyback scheme, particularly in Victoria and also in Queensland under the previous National Party government. It took us one year to get that report out. We found out this time last year that the scheme was basically in danger, but the government had known for a year beforehand. We now know that the problems that were identified in April 1997—problems that were exposed this time last year—are now real problems that affect the effectiveness of the scheme.

We have concerns also at the way that the Prime Minister has handled this particular issue over the last few weeks. On A Current Affair on 24 February, the Prime Minister said to Mike Munro that he was committed and that the whole issue of the national gun buyback scheme would be the number one priority on the agenda at the Premiers Conference in April. With all the earnesty that he trumps up for A Current Affair, he said:

I make it very clear on your program that we will use any power at our disposal to prevent any serious watering down of those laws and we have in fact withheld compensation payments to at least one of the states because they have diverged slightly from the rules that were agreed to . . .

He went on to say that this would be the number one priority on the agenda at the Premiers Conference in April. What has happened since then is quite obvious. The Prime Minister was obviously intimidated by Premier Kennett, to the extent that that issue that he promised to raise on the Premiers Conference agenda as the number one priority issue was not raised. In fact, the Prime Minister ran dead—intimidated by the Premier of Victoria, who has always got his measure on these sorts of issues.

The other concern that we have is that the scheme is falling apart in a very substantial manner. If you have not got a buyback operation in Victoria, then you have a real problem. But you have this real problem because Victoria has consistently refused to adopt a 28-day cooling off period on second purchases. They also want access to category C weapons for the Victorian Field and Game Association.

Those issues in themselves are grave enough, but for the Prime Minister to basically tell the Australian public—on the highest rating afternoon news and current affairs program—that he would raise this as the number one issue, and then to drop the ball and to wimp it against Premier Kennett, is to let down his obligations and his responsibilities to the Australian people. We on this side of parliament are concerned. The national gun law scheme was developed by Duncan Kerr, a former Minister for Justice in the Keating government, but it was augmented because of the events at Port Arthur to pick up the particular problems at Port Arthur. So in a sense we all have a joint interest in it, and we will maintain that interest. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I note the comments of Senator Bolkus, and I think everybody in this chamber at some time or other has had concerns about gun laws and the buyback scheme. It has been a very complicated issue. Of course, we must remember that today is the third anniversary of the tragedy at Port Arthur and that the ramifications are still being felt in that community. I note that there will be a memorial service today. I note also that it has been suggested that, since that tragedy, there have been one or two suicides of people who were involved.

speech.para: The opposition have come in here today trying to point the finger at the government and saying that we have not been taking enough action. The fact is that the guns buyback scheme ended on 30 September 1997. The number of guns surrendered was 643,726 guns and $397 million has been paid in compensation to gun owners as at 9 April this year. Sixty-three million dollars was allocated for payment to states and territories for administration and $400,000 was set aside for a national firearms register. A total of $458,000 had been paid as at 9 April this year.

I understand that compensation to dealers for loss of business has not yet been finalised, but this is a long, drawn out and complicated arrangement. It is something that has virtually never happened anywhere else in the world. Perhaps if some of the states in America had taken this action, when this government and the Prime Minister took strong action after the Port Arthur tragedy, we would not have seen the sorts of disasters and horrific occurrences recently in America. You have only to hark back to earlier in the week to see what happened at that school in Littleton, Colorado. We live in a violent society. This government, through our Prime Minister, has taken very strong, positive action with the support of all parties in this chamber, and I really think it is a bit below the belt for Senator Bolkus to come in here today to try to nitpick at what the government has been doing.

As I said, over 600,000 guns have been surrendered and nearly $400 million has been paid out in compensation to the gun owners. It was a very sore point with a lot of farmers around the areas. They did not like having to register their guns and having the complications that go with that but, all in all, people accepted that. The only problem is that, every time someone like Senator Bolkus or some other party raises the issue, it does bring back memories to some people who had strong views about handing in their guns and it creates a fair amount of angst in some areas of the community.

So I think the action taken, and that is continuing to be taken, by the minister, Senator Vanstone, is appropriate. I understand that all the states and territories agreed in 1996 to national uniform gun laws to restrict ownership of high-powered semiautomatic weapons. That process has been successful. As I said, we have had a huge number of guns handed back and a huge amount of compensation has been paid. While some people still feel very sorely about having to hand in guns of high or antique value, it has been a successful exercise. There are still violent crimes relating to firearms in our communities, but I think we would all have to agree that the strong action taken by Prime Minister Howard and this government, receiving bipartisan support from other parties, has worked and has helped to reduce the number of violent gun-related crimes in Australia.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the comments of my colleague Senator Bolkus and also to contribute to this motion to take note of answers given by Senator Vanstone during question time today. The issues involved in the questions put to Senator Vanstone today were of course of great importance—firstly, the issue of the gun buyback and the control of firearms in this country; secondly, the issue of how to deal with that terrible scourge of drug abuse and deaths, particularly through the use of narcotic drugs such as heroin; and, thirdly, the issue of legal aid—that is, the provision of support and assistance to people who need it to obtain a fair hearing in the justice system.

speech.para: Senator Calvert, struggling as he was to deal with the issues raised by Senator Bolkus, referred to the need for bipartisan support. We on this side gave bipartisan support to the Prime Minister's initiatives in respect of the gun buyback scheme. That of course was very much a response brought about by that terrible tragedy at Port Arthur. It is one thing to talk about bipartisan support, Senator Calvert, but it is another thing entirely to deliver it. Frankly, I really get upset with those sorts of comments because I can recall what happened in 1988 in New South Wales when the then Premier, Barry Unsworth, endeavoured to do something about this issue following the Hoddle Street and Strathfield massacres and other instances where a number of people had been killed through the use of firearms. What did the coalition in New South Wales do then? They attacked Premier Unsworth and his gun laws. As a result, the Labor Party suffered electorally. It took a long time, and it had to take another massacre—at Port Arthur—to finally get some bipartisan approach on this, so the coalition's record on that issue is not such a good one.

I will turn quickly to the issue of drugs. What did we see just prior to the last state election in New South Wales? In a pathetic attempt to try to help Mrs Chikarovski and her other coalition colleagues in New South Wales to win the election, Senator Vanstone got up in this parliament on at least seven occasions in question time and answered dorothy dix questions from Liberal-National Party senators on the issue of drugs. On each occasion, she attacked the performance and the policies of the Carr Labor government. That was on seven occasions in five question times, including two supplementary questions. It was nothing more than a political attack to try to support her coalition colleagues in that state election.

Senator Vanstone also issued five press releases—on 29 January, 16 February, 19 February, 3 March and 23 March. On each occasion except one she attacked the New South Wales Labor government. In the 29 January press release she actually said that she warmly welcomed the New South Wales opposition antidrugs policy and further said, `We look forward to the election of the Chikarovski government in New South Wales on 27 March.' What happened on 27 March? The New South Wales coalition were absolutely slaughtered at that election.

The policies of the Carr Labor government on such important issues as education, health, employment, economic management and particularly law enforcement were endorsed overwhelmingly by the people of New South Wales. They did not buy this cheap, disgraceful, sleazy attack from Senator Vanstone in that last desperate attempt to try to prop up her coalition colleagues. They saw through that political attack. They also recognise, as do the New South Wales Labor government and, I believe, decent members of parliament across all political sides, that the issues of drug abuse and crime associated with drugs require bipartisan solutions.

Beginning on 17 May, the New South Wales Premier is convening a five-day conference to be held at the New South Wales parliament. It will involve all state members of parliament from all political perspectives. It will involve experts, it will involve organisations. That is the way to approach this issue—not with the cheap tricks of Senator Vanstone. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I think it is alarming that, on an issue such as the very successful gun buyback scheme initiated by the coalition government, senior senators on the other side say that it is not working. It is clearly working, and I want to put to rest any fears that have been spread or will be spread to the Australian community. I have been involved through most of my life with guns. I handed in several guns. One was an automatic shotgun which I had not used for years. It was really only a showpiece, but I handed it in. I did not like having to, but the rules were the rules.

speech.para: Let me tell you how much the scheme is working. There were 643,726 rifles or guns surrendered. As of 9 April this year, over $397 million—nearly $400 million—had been paid out in compensation to gun owners. Together with $400,000 for the national firearms register, a total of over $400 million was paid out. The levy was intended to raise $500 million. It is true to say that compensation to dealers for loss of business has not yet been finalised—that is still ongoing. But for Senator Bolkus to say that the scheme is falling apart in a very significant manner is nothing more than scare tactics, coming on top of the Columbine High School tragedy in the United States of America. I think it is pretty low politics to use those sorts of tactics when emotions are running high over the deaths of schoolchildren in the United States. It is also low politics because of the tragedy at Port Arthur. It is not good politics.

I want to assure the people of Australia that the scheme is working. The Prime Minister introduced the scheme against a lot of opposition, and I did not agree with it at the time, because of my background in the bush, but I agree with it now. There was one area which I did—and still do—disagree with, and that was the trashing of the 643,000 rifles and guns that were brought in. Some of those could have been set up in a museum. Perhaps it would not have held people's attention during these immediate years, but in later years I think we could have had one of the great museums of the world with these guns on display. It would not have been a matter of inspecting the guns out of morbidity but more a matter of seeing the ingenuity of mankind in being able to produce machinery of this nature. Some of them, depending on your view, are indisputably works of art. Some of the handmade guns I can think of which were handed in were worth over $100,000. One that I surrendered was worth something like $1,500. That was a rather attractive piece which showed the manufacturing ability of homo sapiens.

Having been involved with guns and rifles for most of my life—in fact since I was 12 years old—and having been opposed to what initially happened with respect to the gun buyback scheme, I have nothing but congratulations to offer to the government for making the scheme work, particularly in light of what has happened in America. America has the largest gun culture in the world. There are something like 200 million guns in households in America. There are many fewer than that in Australia, although not on a per capita basis. I am surprised—not shocked but surprised—at Senator Bolkus's attack, given that it comes on the back of the tragedy in the United States at Columbine High School and given that that event has been recalled so painfully by Australians who lost loved ones at Port Arthur. I think it is a very sordid way to use this House, and politics of that nature bring this House into disrepute.

talk.start.para: —It had been my intention to direct my remarks to the third element of Senator Bolkus's motion—that is, the matter dealing with legal aid and the response by the Minister for Justice and Customs to my question on legal aid—but I am provoked by the comments by Senator Lightfoot, my Western Australian colleague, who stands here and contradicts the Minister for Justice and Customs, the Prime Minister of Australia and the Premier of Victoria.

speech.para: Senator Lightfoot said that the gun buyback scheme is working and there are no problems with it. Senator Lightfoot was not listening to the comments by the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator Vanstone, who clearly indicated that there are huge problems with the gun buyback scheme—so much so that compensation is being withheld to the state of Victoria because they have not cooperated with the Commonwealth and the gun buyback scheme. There are huge problems with the scheme. It is not working in Victoria, and that is something about which we on this side of the chamber are appalled.

The Prime Minister, and indeed the minister for justice earlier this year at the Senate estimates committee hearings, gave an assurance to the chamber that Victoria would be brought to heel. The Prime Minister followed up what Senator Vanstone said by saying, `Yes, indeed; Victoria will be brought to heel. We will bring this matter as the number one priority item to the Premiers Conference.' Senator Lightfoot would be as aware as anybody else in this chamber that the Premiers Conference has been and gone. What was the priority item at that? What number on the agenda did the gun buyback scheme rate at that Premiers Conference? It did not rate at all. Mr Howard has reneged on the commitment to the parliament of Australia and to the people of Australia. The fact that this issue has been raised at a time of tragedy in the United States is merely coincidence.

talk.start.para: —Rubbish!
—It is merely coincidence, Senator Lightfoot. The Senate estimates committees sit next week, and you can be assured, Senator Lightfoot, as indeed Senator—
—Senator McKiernan, please address the chair.
—Senator Lightfoot can be assured—as indeed Senator Vanstone can be assured—that this matter will be pursued in that forum.

speech.para: Senator Calvert also addressed this matter. Senator Calvert made great weight of the number of weapons that have been handed in from all over Australia, including some from Victoria, and the amount of compensation that has been paid. We are very pleased with that. There has been the utmost cooperation from this side of the chamber, from this side of the parliament, in the gun buyback scheme. When we get figures like that we are pleased, but when there is a breakdown in the system we are prepared to point the finger. We will do everything we possibly can to assist the Prime Minister to assist the Attorney-General and the Minister for Justice and Customs to ensure that the Victorian government plays its part in this scheme as well.

As I indicated, the matter that I really wanted to address my remarks to was the third element of Senator Bolkus's motion—the matter dealing with legal aid and the question I addressed to the Minister for Justice and Customs. The minister in her response to me went to great lengths to point out how the legal aid system is now funded—that the money is delivered for Commonwealth law matters and that the states are obliged to fund the legal aid commissions to fund what are known as state law matters.

The Minister for Justice and Customs overlooked the criticisms of the Chief Justice of the Family Court of Australia, Chief Justice Alistair Nicholson, who alluded to a survey which found that 35 per cent of family law cases were now run with at least one party unrepresented by a lawyer. He attributed that non-representation to the legal aid cuts. Senator Vanstone overlooked the fact that family law is a Commonwealth law matter. Thirty-five per cent of the cases now going before the court are not able to be represented in the Family Court because of the cuts to the tune of $232 million by the Commonwealth government. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise in this debate firstly to say that I think that my colleague Senator Forshaw was very harsh on Senator Vanstone with his criticism. I think Labor Party members throughout the state of New South Wales and indeed in this federal parliament—the Senate and the House of Representatives—congratulate Senator Vanstone for assisting the re-election of the Carr Labor government by her unbelievable attacks—
—Can you thank her formally on our behalf?
—Senator Faulkner, can I have some order please.

—I will do that, Senator Faulkner; indeed, I am doing that now. There is no doubt that there was no credibility at all in the answers given by Senator Vanstone to the dorothy dix questions on this matter. You only have to listen to the answer given today to know that. The material that was put in the question to Senator Vanstone today showed that there is an appalling problem in Victoria, yet Senator Vanstone said, `I've seen that there is a satisfactory, if not more than adequate, policing system in Victoria.' That was the effect of the words of Senator Vanstone.

speech.para: It was also mentioned in the question that perhaps the problem was interdiction. Senator Vanstone would not entertain that, but if you believe Senator Vanstone's answer then the only way you can interpret the problem in Victoria and the magnitude of the deaths due to heroin overdose is a problem with interdiction, and that is the problem that Senator Vanstone has to address. That is why no-one has any confidence in the answers from this minister on this question. Because there is so much heroin getting into this country and the price of heroin is so cheap we have seen a massive problem. The minister for justice has to address this problem and not try to blame the Premier of New South Wales and not try to protect the Premier of Victoria because it suits her politically.

With respect to the question of the gun buyback scheme, Senator Lightfoot attempted to castigate Labor for raising the issue of the recent deaths in the United States—the appalling situation of yet another massacre in a high school there. One only has to look at the United States and their system of control on guns to know that the policy that this government has adopted, with the total support of Labor—after the present government when in opposition opposed every move of the previous Labor government to do something about guns—on gun control is infinitely better than the policy which applies in the United States which permits these awful weapons to be available to children to take into their schools to kill their school mates and their teachers. Frankly, there is something not quite right with those particular people.

It is appalling what is taking place, but more appalling is the United States' system of gun control. They do not have a system of gun control. We have even seen the situation where there are some people in the United States who are prepared to fund political parties in this country that are opposed to our gun control system, because they want to avoid a system where the availability of weapons is severely controlled that compares favourably to their own.

I agree with Senator Calvert that there are people who are opposed to gun control and to the idea that they had to surrender their weapons, but I think everyone agreed—this government agreed and the opposition agreed—that there are things in the greater good that need to occur and gun control was one of them. It is great to see that, at least on issues such as this, there is bipartisan support.

For the minister to admit, as Senator McKiernan has said, that there is a significant problem with the system in Victoria is evidence that this government now has to take action—further action, indeed, to that which it has taken—to ensure that the national gun control policy is properly implemented. If there is a problem with Mr Kennett's government in that regard, they need to take further action to ensure that we do have an adequate, uniform gun control system throughout this country.

I suspect, given the information from the Victorian minister Mr McGrath that they are simply going to pass on the bills to the federal government, that this is an indication that the government's current policies are not working, are not adequate, and that this government will need to do more. I can say that the Australian Labor Party is committed to the implementation of a proper national gun control system throughout Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —A petition has been lodged for presentation as follows:

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned shows that citizens of Tasmania think that the government's taxation package, including the goods and services tax, does not provide sufficient information nor detail and hence is open to inequitable application during its implementation.
Your petitioners ask/request that the Senate should not pass the legislation until the following questions are resolved fairly and equitable for the citizens of Tasmania:

1. How will the government ensure Tasmania is treated fairly in comparison to the more affluent and larger States? Tasmania, on a per capita basis, has the highest unemployment, lowest average weekly wage, the oldest population, the greatest number of people dependent on government income support and the most decentralised population of any state of Australia. The government's model for estimating the cost of the GST does not allow for the different economic and social patterns between states.

2. How will the government ensure families can afford good food which will be relatively more expensive in respect to `junk' foods whose price will decrease after the removal of sales tax? Tasmanians pay the highest costs for food in Australia and are among the worst health status population in Australia.

3. How will the government ensure that organisations and charities can continue to provide the necessary community services and support to disadvantaged citizens? Community organisations and charities in Tasmania will face a double jeopardy from the implementation of the Tax Package. It is predicted that poverty in Tasmania will increase and more people will be seeking extra assistance. At the same time organisations will have a reduced capacity to meet those needs because of increased administrative costs associated with compliance and in many instances reduced revenue because of the application of the tax to such things as membership fees and fund raising.

4. How will government ensure that service quality and scope of education, child care and health services can be maintained without increasing the costs of these services? The government proposes that essential services such as education, child care and health will be GST free. However, community based organisations offering these services will have increased costs arising from the extra administration and accounting requirements of the tax package.
